docs.title: HTML & CSS Basics
docs.text: This chapter introduces the fundamentals of HTML and CSS for building web pages. Step-by-step instructions, code examples, and diagrams are included.

docs.title: 1. HTML Structure
docs.text:
HTML documents have a basic structure:

<!DOCTYPE html>
<html lang="en">
<head>
  <meta charset="UTF-8">
  <title>My First Page</title>
</head>
<body>
  <h1>Welcome to HTML</h1>
  <p>This is a paragraph.</p>
</body>
</html>

Explanation: 1. <!DOCTYPE html>: Declares HTML5 document. 2. <html>: Root element. 3. <head>: Metadata. 4. <body>: Content visible in the browser.

docs.title: 2. Page Layout Diagram
docs.text:
flowchart TD
    A[HTML Document] --> B[Head]
    A --> C[Body]
    C --> D[Header <h1>]
    C --> E[Paragraph <p>]

The diagram above shows the relationship between the main sections of an HTML page.

docs.title: 3. CSS Basics
docs.text:
CSS adds styles to HTML elements.

<style>
  body {
    font-family: Arial, sans-serif;
    background-color: #f0f0f0;
  }

  h1 {
    color: #0d6efd;
    text-align: center;
  }

  p {
    color: #333333;
    line-height: 1.5;
  }
</style>

Explanation: - body selector: Styles the entire page. - h1 selector: Styles all <h1> elements. - p selector: Styles all paragraphs.

docs.title: 4. Step-by-Step Example: Styled Page
docs.text:
<!DOCTYPE html>
<html lang="en">
<head>
  <meta charset="UTF-8">
  <title>Styled Page</title>
  <style>
    body { font-family: Verdana, sans-serif; margin: 40px; }
    h1 { color: darkblue; }
    p { color: darkgreen; }
  </style>
</head>
<body>
  <h1>HTML & CSS Example</h1>
  <p>This page demonstrates basic styling.</p>
</body>
</html>

docs.title: 5. Layout Diagram (Visualizing Boxes)
docs.text:
graph LR
    Body[Body] --> Header[Header <h1>]
    Body --> Content[Paragraph <p>]

This helps students visualize how elements are nested in the page.

docs.title: 6. Next Steps (Copilot-Friendly Prompt)
docs.text: Below are three practical exercises you can give students to practice HTML and CSS. Each exercise includes a short description, a small code snippet to start from, a Mermaid diagram to visualize structure, and a few hints/solutions.

docs.title: Exercise 1 — Simple Navigation Bar
docs.text:
Description: Create a horizontal navigation bar with links, a brand on the left, and links on the right. Use Flexbox for layout and add a hover effect.

Starter code:

<nav class="navbar">
  <div class="brand">MySite</div>
  <ul class="nav-links">
    <li><a href="#">Home</a></li>
    <li><a href="#">About</a></li>
    <li><a href="#">Contact</a></li>
  </ul>
</nav>

<style>
.navbar {
  display: flex;
  justify-content: space-between;
  align-items: center;
  background: #0d6efd;
  padding: 10px 20px;
}
.nav-links { list-style: none; display: flex; gap: 16px; margin: 0; padding: 0; }
.nav-links a { color: #fff; text-decoration: none; padding: 6px 8px; border-radius: 4px; }
.nav-links a:hover { background: rgba(255,255,255,0.15); }
.brand { color: #fff; font-weight: bold; }
</style>

Visual diagram:

flowchart LR
    Navbar[Navbar .navbar]
    Navbar --> Brand[Brand .brand]
    Navbar --> Links[Links ul.nav-links]
    Links --> Link1[Home li > a]
    Links --> Link2[About li > a]
    Links --> Link3[Contact li > a]

Hints / Solution notes: - Use display: flex and justify-content: space-between to position brand and links. - Remove default list padding/margins from the <ul>.

docs.title: Exercise 2 — Card Layout with Flexbox
docs.text:
Description: Build a simple card component with an image, title, and description. Arrange multiple cards in a row that wrap on smaller screens.

Starter code:

<div class="card-row">
  <article class="card">
    <img src="https://via.placeholder.com/300x150" alt="Placeholder">
    <h3>Card Title</h3>
    <p>Short description of the card content.</p>
  </article>
  <article class="card">...</article>
  <article class="card">...</article>
</div>

<style>
.card-row { display: flex; gap: 20px; flex-wrap: wrap; }
.card { background: #fff; border-radius: 8px; box-shadow: 0 1px 4px rgba(0,0,0,0.1); padding: 12px; width: 300px; }
.card img { width: 100%; border-radius: 6px; }
</style>

Visual diagram:

graph LR
    Row[.card-row (flex wrap)] --> Card1[.card]
    Row --> Card2[.card]
    Row --> Card3[.card]
    Card1 --> Img[img]
    Card1 --> Title[h3]
    Card1 --> Desc[p]

Hints / Solution notes: - Use flex-wrap: wrap so cards flow to the next line on narrow screens. - Set a fixed max width on .card so multiple cards fit side-by-side on larger screens.

docs.title: Exercise 3 — Responsive Image Gallery (CSS Grid)
docs.text:
Description: Create a responsive gallery using CSS Grid that shows 3 columns on desktop, 2 on tablet, and 1 on mobile.

Starter code:

<div class="gallery">
  <figure class="photo"><img src="https://via.placeholder.com/400x300" alt=""></figure>
  <figure class="photo">...</figure>
  <figure class="photo">...</figure>
  <figure class="photo">...</figure>
</div>

<style>
.gallery { display: grid; gap: 12px; grid-template-columns: repeat(3, 1fr); }
.gallery img { width: 100%; height: auto; display: block; border-radius: 6px; }

@media (max-width: 900px) {
  .gallery { grid-template-columns: repeat(2, 1fr); }
}
@media (max-width: 600px) {
  .gallery { grid-template-columns: 1fr; }
}
</style>

Visual diagram:

flowchart TD
    Gallery[.gallery (grid)] --> Photo1[.photo]
    Gallery --> Photo2[.photo]
    Gallery --> Photo3[.photo]
    Gallery --> Photo4[.photo]

Hints / Solution notes: - Use grid-template-columns with repeat() for concise column definitions. - Use media queries to change the number of columns at breakpoints.

You can paste these exercises directly into the chapter to give students hands-on practice. For each exercise, encourage them to try modifying colors, spacing, and responsive breakpoints to see the effects.

docs.title: Web architecture
docs.text:
Web architecture is the high-level design that defines how web applications are structured and how components interact. Typical components include clients (browsers or apps), servers (web servers, application servers), databases, and optional services such as caches, CDNs, and load balancers. The architecture can be simple (single server) or distributed (microservices, APIs, edge services).

flowchart LR
    Browser[Client (Browser / App)] -->|HTTP/HTTPS| LB[Load Balancer]
    LB --> Web[Web / App Servers]
    Web --> DB[(Database)]
    Web --> Cache[(Cache)]
    CDN[CDN] -.-> Browser

Key concepts: - Separation of concerns: UI (client) vs business logic (server) vs data (database). - Stateless servers: keep requests independent to improve scalability. - Horizontal scaling: add more instances behind a load balancer.

docs.title: Client–server model
docs.text:
The client–server model is a communication pattern where the client initiates requests and the server responds. Clients are typically web browsers or mobile apps; servers host APIs and application logic. Requests follow a request → response cycle and commonly use HTTP/HTTPS as the transport protocol.

sequenceDiagram
    participant C as Client
    participant S as Server
    C->>S: GET /api/items
    S-->>C: 200 OK + JSON payload

Short client example (browser using fetch):

<script>
async function loadItems() {
  const res = await fetch('/api/items');
  if (!res.ok) throw new Error('Network error');
  const items = await res.json();
  console.log(items);
}
loadItems();
</script>

Short server example (Node.js using built-in http):

// simple HTTP server (Node.js)
const http = require('http');
const server = http.createServer((req, res) => {
  if (req.url === '/api/items') {
    res.writeHead(200, {'Content-Type': 'application/json'});
    res.end(JSON.stringify([{id:1, name:'Item A'}]));
  } else {
    res.writeHead(404);
    res.end();
  }
});
server.listen(3000);

docs.title: HTTP / HTTPS
docs.text:
HTTP (Hypertext Transfer Protocol) is the foundation for data exchange on the web. HTTPS is HTTP over TLS/SSL and provides encryption, integrity, and server identity verification. Best practices: - Use HTTPS in production (obtain certificates from a CA or Let's Encrypt). - Redirect HTTP → HTTPS to avoid mixed-content issues. - Set security headers (Content-Security-Policy, Strict-Transport-Security, etc.).

Example: simple curl request over HTTPS

curl -i https://example.com/

Example: redirecting HTTP to HTTPS in Express (Node.js)

app.use((req, res, next) => {
  if (req.headers['x-forwarded-proto'] !== 'https') {
    return res.redirect(301, `https://${req.hostname}${req.originalUrl}`);
  }
  next();
});

Further reading - HTTP: RFC 7230–7235 - TLS: RFC 8446 (TLS 1.3)
